tweet: The Defense Community Infrastructure Program, or DCIP, helps communities around defense installations improve roads and vital infrastructure. After 5 years of working to implement DCIP, I’m proud that this year it received $50 million in funding. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/f2dBAtMiqr

The Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act has been expired for years. I’m proud that we have bipartisan support for reauthorizing this critical program, which will address the housing crisis in Indian Country. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/OvjguNoaaF

The Wounded Knee Massacre was 129 years ago today. Nearly three decades ago, Congress recognized the incident as the tragic massacre that it was. This year I introduced a bill rescinding the medals of honor given for the killing of innocent Lakota people. https://dennyheck.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/reps-heck-haaland-and-cook-introduce-the-remove-the-stain-act …

“While many of us regard JBLM as just another member of the Puget Sound community, it is first and foremost a sensitive and secure military installation.” https://www.thenewstribune.com/opinion/article238682823.html …

Puget Sound is the heart of Western Washington, and we need to restore and protect it. That’s why @RepDerekKilmer and I introduced the PUGET SOS Act. I’m grateful to @RepRickLarsen and @RepPeterDeFazio for getting the bill passed in committee unopposed. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/Y8kQgMfbrV

It is our duty to support every person who puts on our nation’s uniform in every way we can. I’m sponsoring the Veteran HOUSE Act with @RepScottPeters to address and alleviate veteran homelessness. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/UDJByWeZt9

Indian Country is struggling with housing affordability and homelessness. I introduced the bipartisan Tribal Access to Homeless Assistance Act, which allows tribes to access federal homeless assistance grants. It passed the House unanimously this November. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/nSNljfpc58

Stormwater runoff, which brings chemicals from roadways and industrial areas into our waterways, is the biggest source of water pollution. The bill I introduced proposes innovative ways to deal with this runoff to protect bodies of water like Puget Sound. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/TqlHgd6jjX

Eva G. Hewitt was the first woman to hold the title of ‘postmaster’ in Tumwater. She has earned her place in the South Sound history books that she helped write. It’s fitting that this bill was signed into law as we celebrated Tumwater’s 150th birthday. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/dvAjH9xYDP

This year I introduced the Climate Security Intelligence Act, and I’m proud to report that we secured the creation of a Climate Security Advisory Council in this year’s defense authorization bill. Climate change is here, and we need to be ready for it. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/8sVxyeblo7
Wishing you a peaceful and joyful holiday on the first night of Hanukkah. pic.twitter.com/PeNNTGCyE5

More homebuyers and renters want to live near public transit. So my friend @RepScottPeters and I introduced the Build More Housing Near Transit Act, which puts housing development at the center of @FTA_DOT’s decisions of how to allocate money for new transit. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/W5H1e1A2K7

Housing costs are out of control across the South Sound and throughout the country. The YIMBY Act encourages local governments to adopt proactive housing policies that will enable more affordable construction and drive down costs. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/kfiGqg2pMf

The SAFE Banking Act gets cash off the streets by allowing banks to provide services to legitimate cannabis businesses. It’s the first marijuana bill to pass a chamber of Congress in more than 50 years, and it did so with a bipartisan 321-103 vote. #12BillsOfChristmas pic.twitter.com/r0tRIaeSuF

The heart of my job as your representative is listening to you about the challenges you're facing and looking for ways to help solve them. I’m glad Chair Powell and the Fed are taking their full employment mandate seriously, and recognize that American workers still haven’t gotten the raise they deserve. pic.twitter.com/aoGngc4xWT

We’re winning the argument: Unemployment has continued to decline far below what experts had targeted, and we still haven’t reached full employment. 

As Chair Powell told me in June, “Wages are missing ten years of growth.” pic.twitter.com/pLTDnb6DOO

The Fed’s mandate is “full employment.” But what does that mean?

To experts? A target unemployment rate.

To me, it means anyone who wants a job has one, so employers have to raise wages to attract workers. That’s why I’ve asked the Fed Chair: “When does America get a raise?” pic.twitter.com/fyfzKCryuy

Before incomes fully recovered, experts declared victory:

"As Fed officials and economists declared that the economy was at or near full employment, some predicted that job gains would soon slow and wages would rise much more quickly.

But they didn’t." https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/12/12/business/economy/fed-full-employment.html …

At the peak of the 2000s, median incomes were no higher than the 1970s after adjusting for inflation—a generation with no real wage growth. One of my missions when I came to Congress in 2012 was to solve that. But we nearly didn’t, as a great new @nytimes article shows.

The historic #ParisAgreement was ratified four years ago today. Re-entering this agreement is a critical first step towards ensuring a safe future and livable planet for our children. This is not a drill. We must act now.

This summer, I visited Yellowstone National Park and saw firsthand how climate change has already ravaged our natural lands. And it's only getting worse. https://twitter.com/RepDennyHeck/status/1169687431592972288 …

The bottom line: this bill is a responsible solution that will reduce drug prices for thousands of Washingtonians, improve Medicare coverage, and make smart investments to improve the health of all Americans. I'm proud we passed  #HR3 out of the House today. (14/14)

Lastly, the bill uses these savings to invest in biomedical research to find cures for the most devastating diseases. And it makes investments to respond to some of our most urgent health issues: health worker shortage, maternal mortality crisis, and opioid epidemic. #HR3 (13/14) pic.twitter.com/l8YsFFxv7x

The savings from lower Medicare drug spending are so large that #HR3 also expands Medicare to cover dental, vision and hearing care for all beneficiaries. These are critical elements of total health care, and including them in Medicare is a great achievement. (12/14) pic.twitter.com/bj73IXNcuF

For Medicare, the savings are plowed back into improved benefits for seniors. For Medicare beneficiaries, the bill creates a limit on out-of-pocket spending and adds new subsidies for low-income seniors. #HR3 (11/14) pic.twitter.com/Fg4e8Ai1xb

These lower prices will be available to both Medicare beneficiaries and individuals with private insurance. This will translate into lower premiums and lower cost sharing for people with private insurance. #HR3 (10/14)

The bill also imposes financial penalties on drug companies that dramatically hike their prices. To give context, the average annual cost of prescription drugs rose nearly 58% between 2012 and 2017. That number should concern all of us. #HR3 (9/14)

Now onto the details: 

This bill requires HHS to negotiate prices for 50-250 drugs per year (drugmakers will face stiff financial penalties if they refuse to negotiate). Budget experts say the lower prices will reduce fed spending by $456 billion over the 2020s. #HR3 (8/14)

For years, my colleagues—including my friend, the late Elijah Cummings—worked to make drug price negotiation a reality. Many of these ideas inspired the bill we passed today, #HR3, which is why it is formally named the Elijah E. Cummings Lower Drug Costs Now Act (7/14)

Medicare, which provides health coverage to 60 million Americans, lacks the power to negotiate drug prices. Almost $1 of every $5 spent in Medicare now goes to prescription drugs, and the total cost over the next decade will be in the trillions of dollars. #HR3 (6/14)

Parts of our government already negotiate drug prices. The VA is allowed to negotiate prices for the drugs it buys for veterans, and drug companies are required to provide price discounts to Medicaid. As a result, the VA and Medicaid pay much lower drug prices. #HR3 (5/14)

These problems don’t happen in other countries. The reason prescription drugs are cheaper abroad than in the U.S. is because those governments take a more active role in negotiating lower prices. #HR3 (4/14) pic.twitter.com/YwlOZdxMLv

I also hear from constituents who work in the health care industry and see firsthand the impacts of our broken prescription drug market. I received this letter last month from Gordon from Tumwater, and found it particularly moving #HR3 (3/14) pic.twitter.com/uRINbmC3h2

I constantly hear from Washingtonians who are outraged about drug prices in America. I’m especially affected by those reliant on a medicine whose price suddenly skyrockets and constituents who ration medications or forego treatment altogether because of costs. #HR3 (2/14) pic.twitter.com/aBvzDeYzhI

Today is a historic day in the House. We passed #HR3, a bill that drives down prescription drug costs and uses $500B in Medicare savings to expand benefits for seniors.  Before I get into the details of the bill, let me explain what these reforms mean to me: (1/14) pic.twitter.com/nVm60PXoEF

When it comes to climate change, we can’t afford to play catch-up.

My bill would ensure our intelligence agencies exchange and share climate data, equipping these agencies with the tools needed to study and prepare for the climate challenges to come.

Currently, there’s no centralized office for climate-related issues within our intelligence community. As members of the intelligence community have testified, this has left responsibility for analyzing the effects of climate change splintered across various groups and agencies.

The intelligence community has stated loudly and clearly that climate hazards pose a real danger to stability and security across the globe: Mass migration. Food and water shortages. Strains on delicate relations around the world.
 
Climate change is here and we need to be ready.

Proud to share that the creation of a Climate Security Advisory Council will be included in this year’s must-pass defense authorization bill. I first introduced the idea earlier this year in the Climate Security Intelligence Act. Here’s why it matters: pic.twitter.com/aJAiK0L3Vf
